Award.AwardTitle: NRT-IGE: A test bed for STEM graduate student communication training

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
NRT-IGE: A test bed for STEM graduate student communication training

Scientists are often criticized for not engaging more with the general public, causing a widening gap between what scientists do in the lab and what the lay public understands about science. Most scientists are not trained with communication skills that would help them engage with the general public. This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award in the Innovations of Graduate Education (IGE) Track to the University of Missouri-Columbia will seek to remedy this problem by investigating communication training for graduate students and developing ways to assure its effectiveness. This project brings together a highly interdisciplinary team from biology, physics, strategic communication, journalism, theater, creative writing, and visual design to develop and test the means of evaluating the effectiveness of communication training in graduate programs. The novel pilot will draw on communication research outside the sciences and use statistical evaluation of training effectiveness from multiple points of view, including the public's. The project will result in tools and procedures graduate training programs could use to assure the quality of communications training, and eventually provide better communication between scientists and others.

Despite widespread agreement on the need for better science communication and a proliferation of training programs, there is little evidence about what approaches actually improve scientists' communication skills. An interdisciplinary team will develop a controlled test bed for communication training in science graduate programs. Longitudinal studies will assess trainees' acquisition and retention over five learning modules. A rigorous statistical design will relate trainees' self-evaluations and instructors' evaluations to responses to survey instruments by hundreds of non-science audience members. Statistical comparison of pre-, post-, and no-training impacts on audiences will establish effectiveness. Trainees will come from the life sciences and later from physical sciences to determine the program's transferability among disciplines. These experiments will provide an innovative model for training evaluation that can be adopted by other programs at relatively low cost.

The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new, potentially transformative, and scalable models for STEM graduate education training. The Innovations in Graduate Education Track is dedicated solely to piloting, testing, and evaluating novel, innovative, and potentially transformative approaches to graduate education.

This work is supported, in part, by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Today’s science, technology, engineering, math and medical (STEMM) graduate students will enter an employment environment requiring skills not normally acquired during graduate training. Foremost among the training absent in STEM graduate education is communication training. Interacting with the public, policy makers, patients, and even scientists in other disciplines requires a kind of communication tool kit that differs dramatically from that provided by even the best STEMM graduate programs. This view has become popular among scientists and communicators, and communication training events and programs are proliferating. But it is not clear what training approaches are most effective and how to evaluate effectiveness. There have been no controlled studies, and evaluation is usually done within the program - querying trainers and trainees - rather than with target audiences, such as the nonacademic public. 

  This project assembled an interdisciplinary team of communication educators and developed a 10-week training program for STEMM grad students that was evaluated and modified as the project proceeded. The differing contributions to training effectiveness made by 4 educators from different disciplines (biological sciences, strategic communication, theater, architecture) were assessed and compared. The most innovative aspect of this project was the use of the Qualtrics online survey/evaluation tool to engage a large nonacademic pool of evaluators to rate 3-minute research presentations. Surveys provided quantitative data concerning multiple aspects of presentation quality before and after training. These results were compared with surveys of trainers and trainees to determine whether program participants and the target audience agreed about the impact of training and if so, how.  

  The project found that a nonacademic audience could detect the impact of training, particularly in the demeanor of the presenters. The audience's perspective was mirrored by the participants. For example, there were significant impacts of training on the speakers' apparent confidence according to both trainees and their audience. On the other hand, trainers generally rated presentation improvement as greater than did audiences. Since reaching the audience (and not the trainers) is the main goal of such training, this suggests that program design and evaluation needs to be done by appropriate test audiences. One of the most influential aspects of training was continuing practice with critical feedback from trainers. This suggests that short-term training may not be as effective as longer programs. Training based on theatrical techniques was found to be particularly influential, as was the degree of active engagement (active learning) by the trainees during the training sessions. 

  The project enhanced the broader impacts of science by producing a cadre of superior science communicators. Trainees reported increased willingness and enthusiasm for public engagement and many reported positive impacts on their subsequent communication efforts. A few redirected their career goals in the direction of science communication, and some trainees developed a very successful "Science on Tap" program featuring graduate student research.
